Thinking Allowed – conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we're going to explore behavioral memories
associated with cases of the reincarnation
type.
With me is Dr. James Matlock, an anthropologist
who is the co-author with Irlander Haraldson
of a recent book called I Saw a Light and Came
Here – Children's Experiences of Reincarnation.
He also contributes articles to the Psi Encyclopedia
published by the Society for Psychical Research
in England.
He is, as I mentioned, an anthropologist and
the author of dozens of academic papers on
reincarnation, parapsychology, anthropology, and related areas.
Welcome, Jim.
Thanks, Jeff.
I'm glad to be here.
It's a pleasure to be with you.
Once again, we've been delving into reincarnation.
We're taking, I guess you might say, a deep dive.
We've done three previous interviews now.
I want to encourage our viewers to check out.
But the theme now are behavioral memories, and that's an interesting topic.
Let's define first of all for our viewers what we mean by a behavioral memory.
Okay, well, behavioral memories are behaviors
shown by the subject of a reincarnation case.
That is, a child typically who recalls a previous
life that are consistent with the person whose
life he recalls.
That is, the child behaves in ways like the previous person behaved.
It reminds me in a way, I know we haven't
touched on this yet, but I know you're aware
there's a literature in the field of heart and
lung transplants where a person who receives
a transplant from a donor, a deceased donor,
often acquires some of the behaviors that
were associated with that donor.
Yes, and those are really very interesting cases.
Unfortunately, it's hard to research them because of confidential issues maintained
by the hospitals.
Hospitals who do the transplants normally want to keep the donors and the recipients
as separate from each other.
So it's only occasionally that the donor becomes
known, and then it becomes possible to compare
certain behaviors that the recipient has shown.
Some of these are really very bizarre behaviors.
One I recall, the recipient started, I think
it was of a heart or maybe heart-lung, started
calling his wife by the name of his donor's wife.
But there are other things that are more strictly behavioral as well.
Yes, and those are similar to what we see in the reincarnation cases.
But in the reincarnation cases, we have the
added element that the children are remembering
a specific previous person with whom they are identifying.
So in addition to talking about memories that

Right, there's not.

subject as the child who remembers that life.

Well, what are some of these prodigious skills?

I see.

There's an Indian boy who...

slit.
Oh.

The cohort, yes.

I seem to recall a case of...which the previous

Of snakes, right.
Exactly.
Yeah.

Well, another type of behavioral memory would

of the previous person.
That's right.

I mean, it's not simply that they describe

with them.

been possible to take what the children say,
they give enough information, names of places

person.
And then when they meet the previous family,

Yeah, when she was a girl, yeah, right, a girl subject, right.

Stevenson has a case where the previous person had not gotten along with his wife.

So this shows that there's a lot of continuity then.
Exactly, yeah.
So it's not just the memories that are being

And I might mention that when Stevenson first

And yet they're consistent with the memories,

Well, are there memories or behavioral patterns associated with gender identity?
Yes.

When there are differences of sex, the children

Yes, yeah, it is very interesting, and it's true.
